<ce:caption id="cap0010">

</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

elements.content:

</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  The 2D network structure of 1 formed via hydrogen bonding interactions.

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  The 1D structure of 2, showing the coordination environment of Mg(II) atom. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

</ce:caption>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Reactions of Hpytza (Hpytza = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-acetic acid) with M(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (M = Co(II), Mg(II), Ca(II)) with the presence of KOH under hydrothermal conditions, produced three novel coordination compounds, [M(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (M = Co(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Mg(<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Ca(<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)). These compounds were structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows mononuclear structure while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> reveal 1D structures via bridging pytza as linker. Furthermore, the luminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at room temperature in the solid state were investigated and the thermal stabilities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were discussed, as well.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reactions of Hpytza (Hpytza = 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-acetic acid) with M(NO3)2 (M = Co(II), Mg(II), Ca(II)) with the presence of KOH under hydrothermal conditions, produced three novel coordination compounds, [M(pytza)2(H2O)2] (M = Co(1), Mg(2), Ca(3)). These compounds were structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 shows mononuclear structure while 2 and 3 reveal 1D structures via bridging pytza as linker. Furthermore, the luminescence properties of 1-3 at room temperature in the solid state were investigated and the thermal stabilities of 1-3 were discussed, as well.

Ligands are often designed in order to engineer the formation of specific lattice structures, however, in the case of complex multifunctional molecules, the crystal packing can be rather unpredictable. Due to its multiple coordination modes the chemistry of the tetrazoles and derivatives with some metals have been extensively investigated, and a number of interesting metal–organic coordination compounds with tetrazole-based ligands were obtained. These compounds not only showed their unique structures but also displayed their interesting chemical and physical properties such as second harmonic generation (SHG), fluorescence, ferroelectric, dielectric behaviors and magnetic interaction properties and so on . As is well-known, carboxylate O atoms and tetrazolyl ring N atoms have good coordination capacities. So, tetrazolecarboxylic acid ligands are excellent and versatile building blocks for the construction of novel coordination compounds . For some time, we have been interested in the synthesis and characterization of coordination compounds containing tetrazolecarboxylic acid ligands . In our previous work, we have selected a new tetrazolecarboxylic acid ligand, 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-acetic acid (denoted as Hpytza) and reported the synthesis, crystal structures and luminescent properties of [Zn(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and [CdCl(pytza)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
. Unfortunately, the complexes of the Hpytza or pytza ligand have been less studied , to the best of our knowledge. To extend our research, we have endeavored to further investigate coordination compounds with other metal ions, for the purpose of obtaining more intriguing structures and acquiring potential advanced materials. As expected, the reactions of M(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (M = Co(II), Mg(II), Ca(II)) and Hpytza produced three new M(II)/pytza complexes, [M(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]. elements.clean_text:
Hpytza metal [Co(II), Mg(II), Ca(II)] complexes were prepared.

The luminescence properties of 2 and 3 were investigated in the solid state.

The thermal stabilities of 1-3 were discussed.

Introduction

The design and preparation of novel hybrid materials, whose properties arise from the formation of defined interactions throughout the lattice, e.g. hydrogen-bonding, stacking networks, porosity, and formation of cavities, requires extensive knowledge of the solid state structural behavior of the targeted metal/ligand systems . Ligands are often designed in order to engineer the formation of specific lattice structures, however, in the case of complex multifunctional molecules, the crystal packing can be rather unpredictable. Due to its multiple coordination modes the chemistry of the tetrazoles and derivatives with some metals have been extensively investigated, and a number of interesting metal-organic coordination compounds with tetrazole-based ligands were obtained. These compounds not only showed their unique structures but also displayed their interesting chemical and physical properties such as second harmonic generation (SHG), fluorescence, ferroelectric, dielectric behaviors and magnetic interaction properties and so on . As is well-known, carboxylate O atoms and tetrazolyl ring N atoms have good coordination capacities. So, tetrazolecarboxylic acid ligands are excellent and versatile building blocks for the construction of novel coordination compounds . For some time, we have been interested in the synthesis and characterization of coordination compounds containing tetrazolecarboxylic acid ligands . In our previous work, we have selected a new tetrazolecarboxylic acid ligand, 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-acetic acid (denoted as Hpytza) and reported the synthesis, crystal structures and luminescent properties of [Zn(pytza)2(H2O)2] and [CdCl(pytza)]n . Unfortunately, the complexes of the Hpytza or pytza ligand have been less studied , to the best of our knowledge. To extend our research, we have endeavored to further investigate coordination compounds with other metal ions, for the purpose of obtaining more intriguing structures and acquiring potential advanced materials. As expected, the reactions of M(NO3)2 (M = Co(II), Mg(II), Ca(II)) and Hpytza produced three new M(II)/pytza complexes, [M(pytza)2(H2O)2]. Herein we report their synthesis, crystal structures, luminescent properties and thermal stabilities.

The elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed with an EA1110-CHNS elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained on a NICOLET380 spectrum using KBr disks in the range 4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out by a Rigaku SCXmini-CCD diffractometer. Hpytza is easily dissolved in water, methanol and ethanol but hardly dissolved in diethyl ether, acetic ether or acetonitrile (

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and instruments

All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. The elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed with an EA1110-CHNS elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained on a NICOLET380 spectrum using KBr disks in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Photoluminescent analyses were performed on an F-4600 fluorescence spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer with the heating rate of 10 °C/min-1 from room temperature to 800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out by a Rigaku SCXmini-CCD diffractometer. Hpytza is easily dissolved in water, methanol and ethanol but hardly dissolved in diethyl ether, acetic ether or acetonitrile ( ).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis of [Co(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Hpytza (0.0820 g, 0.4 mmol) was added to distilled water (2 mL) and the pH value of the solution was adjusted to 6 with KOH (0.2 mol/L). Then C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (6 mL) and Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.0582 g, 0.2 mmol) were added to this solution, respectively. The mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel container, which was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled to room temperature, purple crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained. Yield: 53% based on Co. Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>: C:38.18; N:27.83; H:3.20%. Found: C:38.45; N:27.58; H:3.17%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 1634(s), 1549(m), 1458(s), 1371(s), 1290(m), 1225(m), 1162(w), 1064(w), 1027(w), 826(m), 802(m), 756(w), 730(s), 574(s).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co(pytza)2(H2O)2] (1)

Hpytza (0.0820 g, 0.4 mmol) was added to distilled water (2 mL) and the pH value of the solution was adjusted to 6 with KOH (0.2 mol/L). Then C2H5OH (6 mL) and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0582 g, 0.2 mmol) were added to this solution, respectively. The mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel container, which was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled to room temperature, purple crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 53% based on Co. Anal. Calcd for C16H16CoN10O6: C:38.18; N:27.83; H:3.20%. Found: C:38.45; N:27.58; H:3.17%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1634(s), 1549(m), 1458(s), 1371(s), 1290(m), 1225(m), 1162(w), 1064(w), 1027(w), 826(m), 802(m), 756(w), 730(s), 574(s).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">Synthesis of [M(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] [M = Mg(<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Ca(<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)]</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">An identical procedure as that for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was followed to prepare <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (colorless crystals for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), respectively, except that Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were replaced by M(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O [Ln = Mg (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Ca (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)]. X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals of complexes 1-3 were mounted on a Rigaku SCXmini-CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo K radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 291-293 K. All absorption corrections were performed using the Crystal-Clear programs. The crystal structures of 1-3 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by fullmatrix least-squares using anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms . For 1-3, important crystal data and collection and refinement parameters are summarized in  , and selected bond lengths and angles are given in  , hydrogen-bonding geometry are listed in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

Crystal structures of 1-3 

Crystal structure of 1 

Compound 1 crystallize in the monoclinic space group P2 1 /c and the asymmetric unit of 1 contains half of the [Co(pytza)2(H2O)2] molecule. As shown in  , each Co(II) center lies on an inversion center and is coordinated by four N atoms from two pytza ligands and two O atoms from two water ligands, forming a slightly distorted CoN4O2 octahedral coordination geometry. The pytza anion in 1 acts as a chelating ligand via its one tetrazole N atom and one pyridine N atom, thereby giving a mononulear structure. The crystal structure of 1 is isostructural to that of Zn(II)/pztza complex , hence, only the metal-ligand bond distances and angles have small differences [Co-O(aqua) = 2.087(2) Å; Co-N = 2.142(2)/2.144(2) Å; N(1)-Co(1)-N(5) = 77.22(9)/102.78(9)°].

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Crystal structures of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The X-ray structure analysis reveals that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are isomorphic, here, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is taken as an example to depict the 1D structure in detail. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic> and the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains half of the [Mg(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, each Mg atom is six-coordinated by four O atoms from four pytza ligands and two O atoms from two water molecules [Mg–O = 2.030(2) − 2.1340(19) Å], forming a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Two neighboring Mg(II) ions are doubly bridged by two carboxylate groups from two pytza ligands in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-COO <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> bridging mode, forming a 1D chain extending along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis with Mg⋯Mg distance of 4.5964 Å and the Mg⋯Mg⋯Mg bite angle of 180°. To compare with the Cd(II), Mn(II), K(I)/pztza complexes , each pytza ligand acts only as a bidentate bridging ligand, coordinating to Mg(II)/Ca(II) center via its two carboxylate group O atoms in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, pyridyl-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic> and tetrazole-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic> are not involved in coordination.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures of 2 and 3 

The X-ray structure analysis reveals that 2 and 3 are isomorphic, here, complex 2 is taken as an example to depict the 1D structure in detail. Complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and the asymmetric unit of 2 contains half of the [Mg(pytza)2(H2O)2] molecule. As shown in  , each Mg atom is six-coordinated by four O atoms from four pytza ligands and two O atoms from two water molecules [Mg-O = 2.030(2) - 2.1340(19) Å], forming a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Two neighboring Mg(II) ions are doubly bridged by two carboxylate groups from two pytza ligands in a μ 1,3-COO syn-syn bridging mode, forming a 1D chain extending along the b axis with Mg⋯Mg distance of 4.5964 Å and the Mg⋯Mg⋯Mg bite angle of 180°. To compare with the Cd(II), Mn(II), K(I)/pztza complexes , each pytza ligand acts only as a bidentate bridging ligand, coordinating to Mg(II)/Ca(II) center via its two carboxylate group O atoms in 2 and 3, pyridyl-N and tetrazole-N are not involved in coordination.

The adjacent 1D are held together through one hydrogen bonding interaction between the coordinated water molecule and pyridyl-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic> [O(3)⋯N(5) 2.766(4) Å/165(4)°, −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1/2 − <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>] (), and to generate a 2D network (

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Luminescence properties of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In view of the potential application in the photochemistry area, we endeavored to study the luminescent properties of these coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of <ce:bold>2–3</ce:bold> and free Hpytza ligand were investigated in powder at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). Compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit photoluminescence with emission maximum at 380 nm and 372 nm upon excitations at 328 nm, respectively. These fluorescent emissions could be tentatively assigned to the intraligand (π–π*) fluorescences emission , because a similar emission at 376 nm upon excitation at 328 nm was also observed for the free ligand Hpytza. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not exhibit detectable emission. The reason is complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains Co(II) metal with low energy d–d transitions . These transitions quench luminescence. It is extremely rare that such complexes are luminescent.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties of 2 and 3 

In view of the potential application in the photochemistry area, we endeavored to study the luminescent properties of these coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of 2-3 and free Hpytza ligand were investigated in powder at room temperature ( ). Compounds 2 and 3 exhibit photoluminescence with emission maximum at 380 nm and 372 nm upon excitations at 328 nm, respectively. These fluorescent emissions could be tentatively assigned to the intraligand (π-π*) fluorescences emission , because a similar emission at 376 nm upon excitation at 328 nm was also observed for the free ligand Hpytza. Compound 1 does not exhibit detectable emission. The reason is complex 1 contains Co(II) metal with low energy d-d transitions . These transitions quench luminescence. It is extremely rare that such complexes are luminescent.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Thermal stabilities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). The TG curves for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> show the initial weight loss of 7.20% from 190 to 250 °C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 7.61% from 220 to 280 °C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 7.48% from 140 to 280 °C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively, which can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calculated, 7.15% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; 7.68% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; 7.43% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Further weight loss are probably caused by the decomposition of the pytza ligands beginning at about 250 °C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 280 °C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, leading to the collapse of the frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal stabilities of 1-3 

To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-3 were carried out in the temperature range of 30-800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere ( ). The TG curves for 1-3 show the initial weight loss of 7.20% from 190 to 250 °C for 1, 7.61% from 220 to 280 °C for 2, and 7.48% from 140 to 280 °C for 3, respectively, which can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calculated, 7.15% for 1; 7.68% for 2; 7.43% for 3). Further weight loss are probably caused by the decomposition of the pytza ligands beginning at about 250 °C for 1, 280 °C for 2 and 3, leading to the collapse of the frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Summary</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">In summary, we have reported three novel compounds formed by Hpytza and Co(II), Mg(II) or Ca(II). The results show that the nature of metal ions play an important role in governing the molecular frameworks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and the strong coordination abilities of carboxylate and tetrazolate groups. Compared with the previous work , the Co(II) and Zn(II) metal ions are same coordination mode, the pytza anion in Co(II) and Zn(II) complexes acts as a chelating ligand via its one tetrazole N atom and one pyridine N atom, but each pytza ligand acts only as a bidentate bridging ligand, coordinating to Mg(II)/Ca(II) center via its two carboxylate group O atoms in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, pyridyl-N and tetrazole-N are not involved in coordination.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Summary

In summary, we have reported three novel compounds formed by Hpytza and Co(II), Mg(II) or Ca(II). The results show that the nature of metal ions play an important role in governing the molecular frameworks of 1-3, and the strong coordination abilities of carboxylate and tetrazolate groups. Compared with the previous work , the Co(II) and Zn(II) metal ions are same coordination mode, the pytza anion in Co(II) and Zn(II) complexes acts as a chelating ligand via its one tetrazole N atom and one pyridine N atom, but each pytza ligand acts only as a bidentate bridging ligand, coordinating to Mg(II)/Ca(II) center via its two carboxylate group O atoms in 2 and 3, pyridyl-N and tetrazole-N are not involved in coordination.

Synthesis of [Co(pytza)2(H2O)2] (1)

Hpytza (0.0820 g, 0.4 mmol) was added to distilled water (2 mL) and the pH value of the solution was adjusted to 6 with KOH (0.2 mol/L). Then C2H5OH (6 mL) and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0582 g, 0.2 mmol) were added to this solution, respectively. The mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel container, which was heated at 120 °C for 48 h and then cooled to room temperature, purple crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 53% based on Co. Anal. Calcd for C16H16CoN10O6: C:38.18; N:27.83; H:3.20%. Found: C:38.45; N:27.58; H:3.17%. <ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Luminescence properties of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In view of the potential application in the photochemistry area, we endeavored to study the luminescent properties of these coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of <ce:bold>2–3</ce:bold> and free Hpytza ligand were investigated in powder at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). Compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit photoluminescence with emission maximum at 380 nm and 372 nm upon excitations at 328 nm, respectively. These fluorescent emissions could be tentatively assigned to the intraligand (π–π*) fluorescences emission , because a similar emission at 376 nm upon excitation at 328 nm was also observed for the free ligand Hpytza. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> does not exhibit detectable emission. The reason is complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains Co(II) metal with low energy d–d transitions . These transitions quench luminescence. It is extremely rare that such complexes are luminescent.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Thermal stabilities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were carried out in the temperature range of 30–800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). The TG curves for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> show the initial weight loss of 7.20% from 190 to 250 °C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 7.61% from 220 to 280 °C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and 7.48% from 140 to 280 °C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively, which can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calculated, 7.15% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; 7.68% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; 7.43% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Further weight loss are probably caused by the decomposition of the pytza ligands beginning at about 250 °C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 280 °C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, leading to the collapse of the frameworks.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties of 2 and 3 

In view of the potential application in the photochemistry area, we endeavored to study the luminescent properties of these coordination compounds. The luminescent properties of 2-3 and free Hpytza ligand were investigated in powder at room temperature ( ). Compounds 2 and 3 exhibit photoluminescence with emission maximum at 380 nm and 372 nm upon excitations at 328 nm, respectively. These fluorescent emissions could be tentatively assigned to the intraligand (π-π*) fluorescences emission , because a similar emission at 376 nm upon excitation at 328 nm was also observed for the free ligand Hpytza. Compound 1 does not exhibit detectable emission. The reason is complex 1 contains Co(II) metal with low energy d-d transitions . These transitions quench luminescence. It is extremely rare that such complexes are luminescent.

Thermal stabilities of 1-3 

To characterize the compounds in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-3 were carried out in the temperature range of 30-800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere ( ). The TG curves for 1-3 show the initial weight loss of 7.20% from 190 to 250 °C for 1, 7.61% from 220 to 280 °C for 2, and 7.48% from 140 to 280 °C for 3, respectively, which can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calculated, 7.15% for 1; 7.68% for 2; 7.43% for 3). Further weight loss are probably caused by the decomposition of the pytza ligands beginning at about 250 °C for 1, 280 °C for 2 and 3, leading to the collapse of the frameworks.
